Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of prohibited weapons or substances
Legal_Issue: Can Mr. Cantell's application for an extension of time to appeal the seizure be granted under section 129.2 of the Customs Act?
Application_Facts: Mr. Cantell missed the 90-day deadline but applied within one year; claimed distraction due to his wife’s medical issues; no evidence of bona fide intention to appeal in initial period; second infraction and delay noted
Decision_Outcome: Application for extension of time dismissed
Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to appeal seizure
Court_Ruling: Dismissed as Mr. Cantell failed to meet statutory criteria under section 129.2(4)
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to file appeal within 90 days; delayed action despite personal circumstances
Grounds_for_Claim: Inability to act due to spouse's medical issues; request based on equity and justness
Legal_Standard: Must show: (a) application within one year after 90-day period; (b) inability to act; (c) bona fide intention; (d) just/equitable; (e) made as soon as circumstances permitted
Assessment_Factor: Presence of second infraction; lack of timely action; absence of documented intent to appeal early
Procedural_Issue: Late filing of appeal beyond 90-day window
Credibility_Assessment: No evidence supporting bona fide intention during initial period
Evidence_Used: Personal explanation regarding wife’s health; record of prior customs violation
Application_Basis: Request for equitable relief due to personal hardship
Evidence_Assessed: Lack of documentation or corroboration of claimed distraction
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Minister's denial of extension
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate bona fide intention to appeal within original timeframe
Harm_Assessment: Seizure of items (wine and pepper spray) at customs
Cause_Description: Seizure of prohibited items led to denial of extension request
Evidence_Handling: Considered applicant’s explanation but found insufficient without corroborative evidence
Legal_Provision_Violated: Failure to comply with time limits under Customs Act
Evidence_Issues: Unsubstantiated claim of distraction due to family health issue
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient to establish eligibility for extension
Decision_Rationale: Applicant did not meet all statutory requirements for extension, particularly bona fide intention and just/equitable grounds
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of proof of timely intent to appeal
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory compliance with s. 129.2(4) of the Customs Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to declare goods at customs
Dispute_Type: Administrative appeal – extension of time to challenge seizure
Legal_Issue: Can Mr. Cantell obtain an extension of time under section 129.2 of the Customs Act after missing the initial 90-day deadline?
Evidence_Assessment: Personal issues cited but not substantiated; failure to show proactive steps toward appeal
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate eligibility for extension under s. 129.2(4)
Credibility_Factor: Explanation for delay considered but not accepted due to lack of evidence
Legal_Rule: Extension allowed only if: (1) filed within one year after 90-day period; (2) shows inability to act; (3) bona fide intention; (4) just/equitable; (5) filed as soon as possible
Procedural_Issue: Missed statutory deadline for appeal; request for retroactive extension
Grounds_for_Claim: Personal hardship due to wife’s medical condition
Judicial_Review_Outcome: Upheld Minister's refusal to grant extension
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Process followed statutory framework; opportunity to present case existed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of application; explanation for delay; history of prior offense
Legal_Framework: Customs Act – procedures for contesting seizure
Applicant_Challenge: Seeking leniency based on personal circumstances
Defendant_Response: Minister denied extension; position upheld by court
Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to file appeal
Authority: Minister of Border Services / Federal Court
Legal_Provision_Cited: Sections 129.1 and 129.2 of the Customs Act
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to declare goods resulting in seizure
Governing_Rule: Section 129.2(4): criteria for extension of time
